rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: PowerShell Execution Detection
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution activity using process creation events

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process Detection
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Process Injection
rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Application Layer Protocol
rules.description: Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks using powershell.exe or cmd.exe
Software installation or updates using command line interfaces

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
rules.description: Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate applications using similar command line arguments

rules.title: Windows Management Instrumentation Detection
rules.description: Detects Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) activity via command line analysis
falsepositives: Legitimate administrator activity using WMI for system management
Authorized software installations or updates using WMI

rules.title: Detection: OS Credential Dumping
rules.description: Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Network Service Discovery
rules.description: Detects Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Detection
rules.description: Detects Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Administrators creating scheduled tasks for system maintenance
Users creating scheduled tasks for automated backups

rules.title: Detection: Input Capture
rules.description: Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Screen Capture
rules.description: Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Registry Run Keys Detection
rules.description: Detects Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Administrative tasks using reg.exe or regedit.exe

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please enter your credentials'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $label.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,10); $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing form using PowerShell to test detection of suspicious GUI interactions.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will appear asking for credentials, but it does not collect or send any information.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing email simulation > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a file that simulates a phishing email to test detection of suspicious file creations.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'phishing_email.txt' will be created in the temporary directory with harmless content.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$smtpServer = 'localhost'; $msg = New-Object Net.Mail.MailMessage; $msg.From = 'test@example.com'; $msg.To.Add('test@example.com'); $msg.Subject = 'Phishing Simulation'; $msg.Body = 'This is a test email'; $smtp = New-Object Net.Mail.SmtpClient($smtpServer); $smtp.Send($msg)"
attacks.description: Simulate sending a phishing email using PowerShell to test detection of suspicious email sending behaviors.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email will be sent from and to 'test@example.com' with a subject and body indicating it's a phishing simulation. However, this command requires a local SMTP server to be configured and running.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing email' > phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Creates a text file named phishing_email.txt with a benign phishing-related content to simulate a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_email.txt is created in the current directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign HTML template from a hypothetical example website to simulate downloading a phishing kit or template. Note: This command assumes internet access for demonstration purposes but should be adapted to use local resources in actual testing.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML file named phishing_template.html is downloaded from the specified URL and saved in the current directory.

attacks.description: Sends an email with a subject 'Phishing Test' and the content of phishing_email.txt to a hypothetical email address. This simulates sending a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is sent to the specified address with the subject and content as defined.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of running processes named 'svchost', demonstrating basic PowerShell usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the names of 'svchost' processes.

attacks.description: This command downloads a string from a specified URL using PowerShell, demonstrating intermediate usage with .NET classes for web interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads content from the specified URL.

attacks.description: This command starts a new cmd.exe process that executes the command 'echo Hello World!', demonstrating advanced usage by invoking another executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a new command prompt window and prints 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to list processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes on the Linux system

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command to compress a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the test.txt file into a zip archive named test.zip in /tmp, overwriting if exists

attacks.description: Create a new system service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named MyService will be created and visible in the Services console.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named MyPSService will be created and visible in the Services console.

attacks.description: Start a system service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The MyService service will be started if it exists and is not already running.

attacks.description: Start the SSH service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will be started, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing using the default editor
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing the user to schedule tasks.

attacks.description: Enable and start a custom service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The custom service will be enabled and started, allowing it to run at boot time.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using rundll32 to execute a DLL within the current process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will produce a beep sound, indicating successful execution of the DLL within the current process.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using PowerShell to start notepad and execute calc within it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will start, and within it, the calculator (calc) will be executed, demonstrating process injection.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to start a new process (cmd) and execute whoami within it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new command prompt will start, executing the whoami command, which displays the current user, demonstrating process injection.

attacks.description: Inject code into a running process using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: The injected code will be executed within the target process, allowing for potential malicious activity

attacks.description: Attach to a running process using ptrace
attacks.expected_behavior: The ptrace system call will attach to the target process, allowing for potential code injection

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { execve("/bin/sh", ["/bin/sh"], NULL); }' > inject.c; gcc inject.c -o inject; ./inject
attacks.description: Compile and execute a simple code injection example
attacks.expected_behavior: The compiled code will execute a shell, demonstrating basic code injection

attacks.description: Starting the telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service starts, and the system listens for incoming connections on the default telnet port.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, simulating data exchange via application layer protocols
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World', demonstrating basic application layer protocol usage.

attacks.description: Using certutil to download a file from a URL, simulating command and control communication
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt is downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the temp directory, demonstrating application layer protocol activity for command and control.

attacks.description: Basic: Listen on port 8080 and execute /bin/bash when a connection is established.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a listening port and executes a shell upon connection, simulating a basic C2 channel.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Simulate an HTTP request to a hypothetical server, demonstrating application layer protocol usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP GET request to the specified server, mimicking legitimate web traffic.

attacks.command: while true; do echo -n 'Hello, World!' | nc -l -p 8081 -c; done
attacks.description: Advanced: Continuously listen on port 8081 and send 'Hello, World!' to any connecting client, simulating persistent C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a persistent listener that responds to connections with a predefined message, demonstrating advanced C2 capabilities.

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file in the temp directory using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello'

attacks.description: Intermediate command using powershell.exe to create and invoke a PowerShell script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a PowerShell script in the temp directory and invokes it, displaying 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command using cmd.exe with a for loop to append to a log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends 'Hello World' five times to a log file named test.log in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo $i > /tmp/test_$i.txt; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate command to create multiple files using a bash loop
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates five files named test_1.txt to test_5.txt in the /tmp directory with the content '1' to '5' respectively

attacks.command: bash -c 'while true; do echo Hello World > /tmp/test.txt; sleep 1; done'
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a file and simulate continuous execution using a bash loop
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World' and continuously overwrites it every second

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to decode a Base64 string and write it to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello world'.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to encode a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.enc in the temp directory with the encoded contents of test.txt.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, and then compress it into a zip archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello world', and then create a zip archive named test.zip in the temp directory containing the file.

attacks.description: Basic example of creating an obfuscated file using base64 encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named obfuscated_file.txt in the current directory containing the base64 encoded string of 'malicious_content'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of decoding a previously obfuscated file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the contents of obfuscated_file.txt and saves it to decoded_file.txt in the current directory.

attacks.command: echo 'malicious_script' | base64 | tee obfuscated_script.txt | base64 -d | bash
attacks.description: Advanced example of creating, decoding, and executing an obfuscated script in one step.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an obfuscated script, decodes it, and executes it immediately, demonstrating a more complex evasion technique.

attacks.description: This command simulates exfiltrating a file by first compressing a test file in the temp directory and then uploading the compressed file to a hypothetical server using WebClient.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a compressed archive of a test file in the %TEMP% directory and then attempt to upload this archive to a specified URL, simulating data exfiltration.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to download a file from a URL to the temp directory and then executes it, simulating the exfiltration of a malicious file over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file from a specified URL to the %TEMP% directory and then executes it, demonstrating how malware could be exfiltrated and executed.

attacks.description: This advanced command creates a zip archive of a directory containing data to be exfiltrated and then uses Invoke-WebRequest to upload this archive to a server, simulating exfiltration over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command archives a specified directory, then uploads the archive to a hypothetical server, demonstrating data exfiltration techniques.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using curl to send a file over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of a file to a specified C2 server

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using netcat to send a file over a custom port
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of a file to a specified C2 server over a non-standard port

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using wget to send a file with a POST request
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of a file to a specified C2 server using a POST request

attacks.description: Add a new user to the system, simulating an exploit of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user will be added to the system

attacks.description: Download a malicious payload from a public-facing application, simulating an exploit
attacks.expected_behavior: A malicious payload will be downloaded to the temporary directory

attacks.description: Download a malicious payload from a public-facing application using certutil, simulating an exploit
attacks.expected_behavior: A malicious payload will be downloaded to the temporary directory

attacks.description: Simulate an exploit attempt against a public-facing web application using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to send a payload to a hypothetical vulnerable application, testing detection capabilities without causing harm.

attacks.description: Use wget to simulate posting exploit data to a vulnerable public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command tests detection by simulating an exploit attempt using wget, without actually exploiting any vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: Utilize netcat to simulate an HTTP request that could potentially exploit a vulnerability in a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a crafted HTTP request to test exploit detection capabilities, ensuring safety by not targeting real vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to retrieve the operating system information via WMI, demonstrating basic WMI usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves and displays operating system information.

attacks.description: This command invokes a WMI method to create a new process, in this case, cmd.exe, demonstrating intermediate WMI usage for process creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new cmd.exe process using WMI.

attacks.description: This command retrieves a list of services that are set to start automatically, demonstrating advanced filtering and selection using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the names of services configured to start automatically.

attacks.description: List running processes on the local machine using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes

attacks.description: List running processes on the local machine using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes

attacks.description: Get OS information using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays OS information

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the domain, which can be a precursor to credential dumping activities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts in the domain.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to get local user accounts and their last password set dates, demonstrating how PowerShell can be used for credential-related queries.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local user accounts along with the date their passwords were last set.

attacks.description: Combines listing running services and user accounts, simulating an attacker's reconnaissance for potential credential dumping targets.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays running services and then lists user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Dumping the root user's password hash from /etc/passwd using grep.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the root user's password hash if found in /etc/passwd.

attacks.description: Dumping all user password hashes from /etc/shadow.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output all user password hashes if /etc/shadow is accessible.

attacks.description: Dumping user password hashes using getent, which may not require root for some information.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output available user information, potentially including password hashes if accessible without root.

attacks.description: Enumerate all started services on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running services on the system

attacks.description: Display all network configuration information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network configuration, including IP addresses, subnet masks, and default gateways

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to enumerate all listening TCP connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all TCP connections in the listening state, indicating services waiting for incoming connections

attacks.description: List all listening ports to discover network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all listening ports and the corresponding services.

attacks.description: Scan the local machine for open TCP ports to discover network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of open TCP ports on the local machine.

attacks.command: for port in {1..1024}; do nc -z -w 1 127.0.0.1 $port && echo "Port $port is open"; done
attacks.description: Iterate through ports 1-1024 and check for open services using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of open ports between 1 and 1024 on the local machine.

attacks.description: Basic archive creation using PowerShell, archiving all files in the Public Documents folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.zip in the Public folder containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Intermediate level command using .NET classes within PowerShell to create an archive of the Public Documents folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an advanced_archive.zip file in the Public folder, containing all files and subfolders from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Advanced command using a for loop in cmd to archive files from the Public Documents folder into a tar archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named archive.tar in the Public folder, containing files from the Public Documents folder, demonstrating an advanced method of archiving data.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a directory using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named collected_data.tar.gz in the current user's home directory, containing all files from the Documents directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of archiving specific files (txt files) from the user's home directory using find and tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all .txt files in the user's home directory and its subdirectories, then appends them to an archive named collected_text.tar.

attacks.description: Advanced example of archiving a directory while excluding certain files (tmp files) using tar with the --exclude option.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named important_data.tar.gz containing all files from the Important directory, excluding any files with the .tmp extension.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "My Task" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World!" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a daily task that runs a command
attacks.expected_behavior: Task created successfully

attacks.description: Delete a task
attacks.expected_behavior: Task deleted successfully

attacks.description: Query a task
attacks.expected_behavior: Task information displayed

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open, allowing the user to add a new cron job.

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run a script daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: The script located at /path/to/your/script.sh will be executed daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for a specific user to schedule a task requiring admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open for the specified user, allowing the scheduling of a task that requires admin privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::AppActivate('Notepad'); $oForm = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $oForm.Text = 'Input Capture'; $oForm.Width = 300; $oForm.Height = 200; $oForm.KeyPreview = $True; $oForm.Add_KeyDown({param($sender, $e) if ($e.KeyCode -eq 'Enter') { $sender.Close() } }); $oForm.Show(); Application.Run();"
attacks.description: This command creates a simple form to capture keyboard input using PowerShell. It does not require admin privileges and is considered of medium safety level.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new form window will appear, capturing keyboard input until the Enter key is pressed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Windows.Forms'); $objForm = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $objForm.Text = 'Input Capture'; $objForm.Width = 300; $objForm.Height = 200; $objForm.KeyPreview = $True; $objForm.Add_KeyDown({param($sender, $e) if ($e.KeyCode -eq 'Enter') { $sender.Close() } }); $objForm.Show(); Application.Run();"
attacks.description: Similar to the previous command but uses Reflection to load the assembly, demonstrating an alternative approach to capturing input.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form window will appear, and keyboard input will be captured until the Enter key is pressed.

attacks.description: A basic command using cmd.exe to prompt the user for input, demonstrating input capture using legacy binaries.
attacks.expected_behavior: A command prompt will ask the user to enter input, which is then captured and displayed.

attacks.description: Simulate input capture by testing the second input device (e.g., a keyboard) and logging events.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will log input events from the specified device, demonstrating how an attacker might capture user input.

attacks.description: Capture input from the first input event device (often a keyboard) and save it to a file named typescript.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command captures raw input data from the device, which could be used to reconstruct keystrokes. It requires root access due to the nature of accessing /dev/input/event* devices.

attacks.description: Use xkeysnail to simulate a key press (ctrl+shift+a) when a specific condition is met, demonstrating how input can be manipulated or captured.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command simulates a specific key press, showing how an attacker could manipulate or capture user input in a controlled manner.

attacks.description: Capture the screen using mspaint
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and open the captured image in mspaint

attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and save the captured image as a PNG file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Capture the screen using snippingtool
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and open the captured image in snippingtool

attacks.description: Take a screenshot and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be taken and saved to the current directory

attacks.description: Take a screenshot of the currently focused window and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the currently focused window will be taken and saved to the current directory

attacks.description: Take a screenshot after a 5-second delay and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be taken after a 5-second delay and saved to the current directory

attacks.description: Add a new Registry Run Key to execute cmd.exe on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new key is added to the Registry, causing cmd.exe to run on the next user login

attacks.description: Query the Registry to check if a specific Run Key exists
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks for the existence of a specific Run Key and displays its value if found

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to add a new Registry Run Key, overwriting any existing value
attacks.expected_behavior: A new Run Key is added or an existing one is overwritten, causing cmd.exe to run on the next user login

attacks.description: Appends a command to /etc/rc.local to execute at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' will be printed to the console at the next system startup.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a command at system startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' will be printed to the console at the next system startup.

attacks.description: Creates a new script in /etc/profile.d/ to execute a command at user login
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' will be printed to the console upon the next user login.
